lesson.title: Managing Blockchain Transactions
lesson.summary: Identify various wallet types, private/public key generation between non-deterministic, sequential deterministic, and hierarchical deterministic wallets.

atoms.text:
# Lesson Overview 

Blockchains are a transaction-based system, so the topic of Transactions is important!

In this lesson, you’ll pull together the individual concepts we introduced earlier - keys, blocks, wallets, etc - and understand how they interact together to form a secure transaction.

By the end of this lesson you will:

- Understand the mechanics of a simple transaction between 2 entities (e.g. Joe and Jessica) using private keys, public keys, wallets, and public blockchain.
- Determine and generate the appropriate wallet type for the needs of a given situation. (Non-deterministic, Sequential Deterministic, and Hierarchical Deterministic)
- Create and restore a bitcoin wallet using private keys.
- Recognize signing transactions as a part of the transaction lifecycle and can describe its purpose and process.

Let’s get transacting!

# Blockchain Identity Motivation
This lesson is focused on establishing and working with your own Blockchain Identity. This is a really important concept...but why?

In this section, we'll briefly discuss why understanding these concepts is so important. This will hopefully help you connect some of these new concepts to some of their real world use cases.

# Coinbase CTO, Balaji Srinivasan

In this first video, Coinbase CTO, Balaji Srinivasan discusses why identity is important.

# Interview: Blockchain Identity

Next, take a look at this interview with Brandy where she discusses the importance of blockchain identities, and how these ideas relate to the next project.

# Wrapping Up

Now that we've got a good idea of what we're covering and why it's important, we're ready to move on into some of the content in the lesson! Keep this advice in mind, and try to remember how these new topics relate to the bigger picture of becoming a blockchain developer!

When you're ready, come join us in the next section where we discuss **Blockchain Identity** in more detail.

# Blockchain Identity

Welcome to this section on **blockchain identity**! Like a social security number, a bank account, a drivers license, or a club membership, your **blockchain identity** is how you establish yourself in the world, in this case the blockchain world. 

In this section, we'll go over the basics of blockchain identities. You'll hear many new terms and ideas that will help set you up to create and manage your own personal blockchain identity.

# Blockchain Identity Overview

In this first video, we'll cover things like wallet addresses, private keys, public keys, and more to learn what they are and how they contribute to creating your blockchain identity.

# Blockchain Hashing Algorithms

With a better understanding of the goals and purpose of wallet addresses, private keys, and public keys, we can now look further into how each of these are created.

By using hashing algorithms, blockchains help create our identity in a way that is extremely secure.

In the next video, we'll dive deeper into each of these algorithms to understand how the blockchain ensures the security of our addresses and keys.

## Key Terms

> **Wallet Address**: A unique identifier for your wallet
 
>**Private Key**: A secret number that allows you to spend bitcoin from your wallet.

> **Public Key**: Publicly shareable key that cannot be used to spend bitcoin.

# Problem: Identity Terms

Having learned a bit about keys and hashing algorithms, we're hoping you can take some time to think through the problem below.

complex_prompt.text: Fill in the blanks for the diagram above to cement the relationship between Private Keys, Public Keys, Public Key Hashes, and Bitcoin Wallet Addresses, and the algorithms to interact between them.

atoms.text:
# Wrapping Up

Throughout this section we went over the basics of what makes up a blockchain identity. Things like wallets and keys are extremely common in blockchains and we'll go in more depth about each of these terms throughout the lesson. 

Coming up, we'll take a closer look at wallets, the different types that exist, and how these types of wallets help in different circumstances.

# Wallet Types

Blockchain identities are made up of a few important tools like wallets, addresses, and keys. Not only are there a few of these different tools creating our identity, it's also possible to implement them in different ways. 

The ways these are implemented result in different wallet types. In this section, we'll go over the basics of wallets, and cover different wallet types to help you determine which is right for you.

# Wallet Types Overview

In the next video, we'll look at wallets to discuss a few of the ways they have been used to contribute to the security of our blockchain identity.

## Key Terms

> **Non-deterministic Wallet**: (random wallets) A wallet where private keys are generated from random numbers.

> **Deterministic Wallet**: A wallet where addresses, private keys, and public keys can be traced back to their original seed words.

> **Hierarchical Deterministic Wallet**: An advanced type of deterministic wallet that contains keys derived in a tree structure.

# Wrapping Up

Here we looked at different wallet types like non-deterministic wallets, deterministic wallets, and even distinct types of deterministic wallets like HD wallets.

These can get pretty complicated and there's a lot to know about how each of these wallet types works. In the next section, we'll try to add more clarity to the purpose behind these wallet types by going over each of them in more detail.

# Wallet Types

Previously, you learned the difference between deterministic and non-deterministic wallets. To understand each of them a little better, it helps to focus on each of them specifically and discuss them in a little more detail.

In this section, we'll do a deep dive on these 2 main types of wallets. This will inform decisions you make later on about the wallets you'll use personally or when building your own applications.

# Non-Deterministic Wallets



First, let's take a closer look at non-deterministic wallets.

# Deterministic Wallets

Now that we know a little more about non-deterministic wallets, let's define deterministic wallets a little more clearly to understand how they differ from each other.

# Wallet Scenarios

Coming up we made up a variety of scenarios for you to explore. Based on what you know, consider the situation and decide which type of wallet might be most suitable.
## Scenario 1

question.prompt: I want to create paper wallets derived from one master key so I can store and recover all of them deterministically. Which wallet is used to achieve this?

atoms.text: # Scenario 2

question.prompt: I’m creating a web server that sells widgets and want to generate an unique transaction address for every customer and every address and track it independently. I want to be able to take a master public key and generate a sequence of sub-public keys, each associated with a transaction and put it on a public web server and make sure the web server has no private keys.

atoms.text: ## Scenario 3

question.prompt: A shoe supply chain is being audited. The auditors are given a public key so they can see all the transactions of the sub tree but they can’t unlock it. Which wallet is used to achieve this?

atoms.text: ## Scenario 4

question.prompt: A blockchain social media website uses private keys to secure personal user data. It uses wallets for backend services that use private keys that are not derived from a seed. Which wallet is used to achieve this?

atoms.text:
# Wrap Up

Throughout this section, we looked closer at the differences between deterministic and non-deterministic wallets. Then, you went through a variety of scenarios to help determine which type of wallet is best suited for a given circumstance. 

Coming up, we'll jump back into the contents of the wallet to describe an incredibly important piece to the security of your blockchain identity - private keys!

# Private Keys

Wallets are great, but it's what's inside that counts. Inside wallets you'll find keys! 

In this section, we'll go over what keys are and the purpose they serve. We'll use this to help understand how they contribute to the security of your blockchain identity. From there, you'll generate a few private keys for yourself!

# Private Keys Overview

First, lets go over the basics of what private keys actually are and why they're important.

## Key Terms

Here's a list of key terms as defined in the video above.

>**Private Key:** A 256-bit random number between 1 and 2^256.

> **Entropy:** Lack of order or predictability. The degree of disorder or randomness in the system.

# How to Generate a Private Key

Now that we understand the basics of private keys, let's generate them for ourselves in the next video!

# Generate Your Own Private Key

Finally, now that you know how to generate a private key, it's time to create one for yourself. Choose from one of the methods shown below to generate your own private key.

question.prompt: Choose at least one of the methods below to generate a Private key. Check off the one(s) you tried.

answers.text: Old School - Grab a paper, pencil, and pair of dice. [Detailed instructions here](https://bitcointalk.org/index.php?topic=297077.msg3197393#msg3197393).

Offline wallet generator -  Follow [these instructions](https://github.com/bigmob/cryptosteel-tutorial/wiki/How-to-generate-private-key-offline-with-Bitaddress) to use a wallet generator such as BitAddress offline.
Software wallet such as [Electrum](https://electrum.org/). Find a full list of [Bitcoin wallets here](https://bitcoin.org/en/choose-your-wallet).

atoms.text:
# Wrap Up

In this section we went over the basics of private keys, why they're secure, and how to create one. Afterwards you created one for yourself. Coming up, we'll use our knowledge of wallets and keys to establish our own blockchain identities using a bitcoin wallet.

# Bitcoin Wallet Overview

Wallets types and private keys are interesting, but so far it's all been theory. What we want you to do now is go out and get a wallet for yourself!

Getting a wallet and working with it for yourself helps you see what’s really going on with these new concepts. It also gives you the opportunity to create your very own blockchain identity!

# Choose a Wallet

First, we have to pick a wallet.

atoms.caption: Google search for "bitcoin wallet" to discover wallets you can use to store bitcoin funds.
atoms.alt: Google search for "bitcoin wallet" to discover wallets you can use to store bitcoin funds.

atoms.text:
There’s a lot of wallets to choose from, and any  of them might make sense for you depending on your needs. Feel free to choose any wallet you like, but do some research before installing one for yourself.

A good way to get started is just to google ‘bitcoin wallets’ and start looking around.

## Electrum
For this course, we’re going to use a wallet called Electrum.

We’re using electrum for a few reasons. It works on almost any computer. It’s fast and lightweight. And it includes all the functionality we’ll need.

To use electrum, you’ll need to install it on your computer. Let’s work through the details of how to do that.

### Getting Started with Electrum 
For more information on how to get started with electrum check out the link below. This is an excellent overview of the basic features of this wallet.

[Getting started with Electrum](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WdVlH9N2oKU)

tasks: Follow the [video directions](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WdVlH9N2oKU), go to [Electrum.org](https://electrum.org/#home) to download a wallet

BONUS: Navigate to the ["My Classmates" section in your classroom](https://s3.amazonaws.com/video.udacity-data.com/topher/2018/August/5b843e17_2/2.png), post a screenshot of your Receiving Address, QR, and request amount and see who shares some bitcoins with you!
atoms.positive_feedback: Hope you were were able to get some funds!

atoms.text:
# Restore your Wallet Identity

We’ve all forgotten passwords from time to time, and no one is immune from password horror stories!

There are times you may end up needing to restore your wallet identity.

**This could happen for a few reasons** 

* You might forget your password. 
* You could lose the 2-step verification device. 
* The wallet service might even become unavailable.
* It’s also possible that you lose your computer or it gets stolen. 

Hopefully none of these things happen, but it’s important to be ready just in case!

To help prepare for situations like this, it’s helpful to know how to restore your bitcoin wallet.

# Ways to Restore a Wallet

If you ever need to restore your wallet, there are 2 ways to do it. You can do it with the wallet words you saved, or with the private keys from when you first created your wallet.

## Use a Seed

One way to restore a wallet is using a seed. The ‘seed’ is the 12 words you were given when creating your wallet. If you can remember these words, you can use them to restore your wallet!

The benefit of restoring your identity using the seed is that it can be much simpler than using the private key. It's easier to remember a list of words than a random string of numbers and letters. 

The hardest part to any of this is safely storing or remembering this information for when you need it. Anybody else who discovers the list of words can access the wallet and any funds tied to it. 

So be VERY careful!

## Use a Private Key

Another way to restore a wallet is with a private key.

When restoring a wallet using a private key, there are 2 ways to do it. You can either import or sweep this key, and it’s useful to understand the difference.

### Import a Private Key

When importing a private key, you'll have a source wallet and a destination wallet. The destination wallet is likely filled with a group of private keys already. To import the key you move the private key from the source wallet to the destination wallet.

This results in you getting access to both the source wallet AND the destination wallet.

The downside to importing is that the private key from the source wallet is essentially compromised since it was shared. If someone gets access to the private key from the source wallet, they can access those bitcoins.

See more on how to import a private key at [BitcoinElectrum.com](https://bitcoinelectrum.com/importing-your-private-keys-into-electrum/).

### Sweep a Private Key

When you sweep a private key, you add a private key from a source wallet into the destination wallet. All the bitcoins that belong to that private key are swept from the source wallet over into the destination wallet. 

This is a little different than importing because it completely removes the funds from the original wallet. You’ll now only be using this new wallet to make future transactions.

See more on how to sweep a private key at [BitcoinElectrum.com](https://bitcoinelectrum.com/sweeping-your-private-keys-into-electrum/).

# Which should you choose?

Why would you import or sweep a private key?

Sweep a wallet if you're worried about wallet security.This might happen in the case that you think someone might have access to your private key. Sweeping completely cleans out the wallet so that no one will have access to your bitcoins.

If you are certain no one has gotten access to your private key, and that no one ever will, then you can import the key instead. This is useful in cases where you need the funds to be available from multiple wallets.

When in doubt, stick with sweeping. It’s more secure this way, and it avoids some problems that are associated with importing a wallet.

# Sign a Transaction

When getting started with a wallet, you'll eventually start to make some transactions for yourself. In this section, we're jumping back into theory a bit to explore a few more ideas about what makes those transactions secure. Hopefully this helps give you the confidence to start working with these tools for yourself.

# Sign a Transaction Overview

After creating a transaction there's a few things to consider. 
* How do we know it's valid? 
* Who owns the transaction?

We validate transactions and assign ownership using what's known as a digital signature. These signatures are an important piece underlying the security of the blockchain. In this video, we'll explore this idea further to discuss how signing a transaction works.

# Why are signatures important?

Hopefully you have a better understanding of why transactions are useful. Next, can you explain to us why signing a transaction is important?

question.prompt: Which of these are valid reasons why signing a transaction is important?

answers.text: Identity management with your wallet address

atoms.text:
# Transaction Inputs and Outputs

As we discussed, transactions are made of multiple inputs and outputs. By understanding the inputs, outputs, miners fees, and amount sent, we can determine the balance of users wallets before and after transactions are made. 

In the next quiz, can you determine the balance of Joe's wallet?

question.prompt: Joe's has a wallet balance with 1.03 btc, he sends Brandy 1 btc with a miners fee of .003 btc, which of these is the correct balance for Joe's wallet?

atoms.text:
# Upcoming Workspace

We just covered the basics of signing a transaction. After this course, you'll get a chance to explore how to sign and verify a message (same concept applies for signing a transaction) using the Bitcoin Javascript libraries [bitcoinjs-lib](https://github.com/bitcoinjs/bitcoinjs-lib) and [bitcore-message](https://github.com/bitpay/bitcore-message) in the [Workspace: Verify Message Signature](https://classroom.udacity.com/nanodegrees/nd1309/parts/53eb3bf0-8a05-45ff-b11d-8b993fb8f10b/modules/0337fa81-d6b9-40f0-99aa-891db36c8bbc/lessons/897f4768-6cff-4642-afe3-ed9150bc9f07/concepts/68e4963a-61a8-4dcc-8503-462d1de98510).
